Visited the page, did not see anything new. Is this whole collection the sa=
me old books in English?

Tom Helm
www.toryu-mon.com
NTHK 2015 Chicago Shin=
sa

On Oct 18, 2014, at 6:59 AM, "'Michael Harris / satcho.com' michael@sat=
cho.com [nihontostudy]" <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com> wrote:

> Japanese S=
word Books and Now a Survey
> 
> We have been at this since 1999. First wit=
h a print catalog advertised in the Japanese Sword Society, United States n=
ewsletter and a militaria newsletter called Bansai. If you needed a clip fo=
r your Nambu with specific serial number Bansai was the place to go. The di=
splay ads in both publications was where we first used the dragonfly design=
. Back then it was from a pattern book and later adopted as the logo. Two y=
ears prior I had been told by a book seller in Pennsylvania that there were=
 only three books on Japanese Swords and, "once you have those you have the=
m all." There is no point in speculating on the number of Japanese sword an=
d related titles were published, but suffice to say it are well more that t=
hree.
>            Fifteen-years later I am writing having just purchased a=
 book collection from a collector who was one of my first contacts after fi=
rst subscribing to the JSS/US Newsletter. A number of these books have come=
  back as they were originally purchased from satcho; it is not the first t=
ime that books have returned in this manner or sure. This collection along =
with others recently purchased has prompted this listing and some though on=
 my reflections about different types of books and how each is used, IE: wh=
at is the utility of a given book.  
> 
> Continued; see "Book Survey"
>

ally the many popular out-of-print titles that we carry where stock is limi=
